intro: Sambucus neomexicana var. vestita, commonly known as the Mexican elderberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Caprifoliaceae family and is characterized by its compound leaves and clusters of small, white or pale green flowers. The plant produces dark purple berries that are edible and often used in culinary and medicinal applications. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy plant suitable for xeriscaping in arid regions.
